name: Extraordinary People and Events Trivia Game | People | 10 Questions

questions.text: The story of Anne Frank is familiar to most people. Where was she living and hiding when caught?
questions.explanation:
Netherlands.

	A remarkable experience for anyone to have to endure - especially so for a young girl. A tragically short life.

questions.text: This author's life was profoundly affected when he was subjected to a 'mock execution'.
questions.explanation:
Dostoevsky.

	He was lined up in front of a firing squad (as were others), with the full expectation and belief that his life was about to end. What kind of a devastating impact wwould that have on someone?

questions.text: The story of 'Robinson Crusoe' was apparently based on the real life adventure of Alexander Selkirk, who was marooned on a deserted island. How long was he there?
questions.explanation:
5 Years.

	1704-1709, not quite a full five years.

questions.text: The 'wild boy of Aveyron' was raised in the wild and lived that way - until an attempt at 'rehabilitation' was made'. The boy's name was Victor; who was the individual who tried to bring him back into the civilized world?
questions.explanation:
Jean Itard.

	It was Itard who tried - with mixed results - to socialize this 'feral child'.

questions.text: Joan of Arc was inspired by 'voices' and ultimately led her country to victory. In what war?
questions.explanation:
Hundred Years' War.

	If she was crazy, it worked out well for the country (if not for her). On the other hand ...

questions.text: The founder of Christian Science is considered to be ...?
questions.explanation:
Mary Baker Eddy.

	Cayce was a man with seemingly considerable clairvoyant powers in the early part of the 20th century. Swedenborg had 'supernatural experiences' which changed his life; there is still today a Swedenborg Society. McPherson was an evangelist.

questions.text: The 'Shroud of Turin' is believed by some to be a genuine religious miracle. Where is Turin?
questions.explanation:
Italy.

	Fatima is in Portugal; Lourdes is in France. In both places there have been claims of 'visions' appearing.

questions.text: Which of these World War I poets did NOT perish during the war?
questions.explanation:
Siegfried Sassoon.

	Owen died about a week before the Armistice. Brooke also died in the course of the war - as did Seeger, who wrote (correctly) 'I Have A Rendezvous With Death'. Sassoon survived.

questions.text: Which poet wrote a moving elegy about his own impending execution?
questions.explanation:
Chidiock Tichborne.

	Chidiock Tichborne (or Tichbourne) wrote the poem that begins with 'My prime of youtrh is but a frost of cares ...'. It's masterful and quite moving - especially when you realize that this young talent was executed in a rather grisly manner on the following day.

questions.text: This colorful figure of the 18th century was believed by some to possess special knowledge and powers
questions.explanation:
Saint-Germain.

	S-G is a truly mysterious figure. The others were, too - but not in that time frame.
